clauses.question: 1. What process should the Government use to set a new emissions reduction target in legislation?
clauses.answer: The Government sets a 2050 target in legislation now
clauses.notes: A set target will encourage immediate action and create momentum towards further change.

clauses.question: 2. If the Government sets a 2050 target now, which is the best target for New Zealand?
clauses.answer: Net Zero Emissions - Net zero emissions across all greenhouse gases by 2050
clauses.notes:
This represents an ambitious target, that will once again put New Zealand in a respectable place internationally. Ideally New Zealand
 would also seek to remediate the harm done to the environment by past failures to cover externalized costs of pollution. It is

 important to recognise the varying effects of greenhouse gases, and develop plans to deal with each accordingly. (e.g. long lived
 gases such as nitrous oxide will require a different approach to short lived gases such as methane). A framework for testing new

clauses.question: 3. How should New Zealand meet its targets?
clauses.answer: Domestic emissions reductions only (including from new forest planting)
clauses.notes:
Meeting emissions by purchasing carbon units is fraught with perils, such as the difficulty of accurately setting a carbon price. Internal
 emissions reductions are more accountable, prevent the damage at source and are more likely to result in a green environment in

 New Zealand.

clauses.question: 4. Should the Zero Carbon Bill allow the 2050 target to be revised if circumstances change?
clauses.notes:
Revisions should be allowed to occur if the body of scientific evidence (such as the IPCC report) was to significantly revise its position.
 Economic considerations should not be grounds for revision of the bill, as it is already clear that short term externalization of the

 economic costs of environmental damage make for better business. However it is also clear that the long term consequence of this
 is significant environmental damage.

clauses.question: 5. The Government proposes that three emissions budgets of five years each (i.e. covering the next 15 years) be in place at any given time. Do you agree with this proposal?
clauses.notes:
The use of long term plans that operate across (and despite) changes in government would seem to be a highly effective method of

 ensuring changes are actually made.

clauses.question: 6. Should the Government be able to alter the last emissions budget (i.e. furthest into the future)?
clauses.answer: No - emissions budgets should not be able to be changed
clauses.notes:
Budget changes should only be allowed if the body of scientific evidence demands it, as this is the only way to ensure consistent
 application of the required standard of environmental protection.

clauses.question: 7. Should the Government have the ability to review and adjust the second emissions budget within a specific range under exceptional circumstances? See p36 Our Climate Your Say
8. Do you agree with the considerations we propose that the Government and the Climate Change Commission take into account when advising on and setting budgets? See p44 Our Climate Your Say
clauses.notes:
These constraints seem reasonable, however I believe care needs to be taken to ensure scientific evidence is weighed adequately
against economic considerations.

clauses.question: 9. Should the Zero Carbon Bill require Governments to set out plans within a certain timeframe to achieve the emissions budgets?
clauses.notes:
Without time frames, legislation becomes essentially meaningless and can be stalled into non-existence, or at least complete
ineffectiveness.

clauses.question: 10. What are the most important issues for the Government to consider in setting plans to meet budgets? For example, who do we need to work with, what else needs to be considered?
clauses.notes:
Sustainability, effectiveness, and based on latest evidence. Working groups will need to include the scientific community, New

Zealand citizens and business leaders.

clauses.question: 11. The Government has proposed that the Climate Change Commission advises on and monitors New Zealand's progress towards its goals. Do you agree with these functions? See p42 Our Climate Your Say
clauses.notes:
I believe the Commission should be advisory, with mechanisms to hold the government to account - this will ensure action is taken
and a real cost is imposed when the system is disregarded.

clauses.question: 12. What role do you think the Climate Change Commission should have in relation to the New Zealand Emissions Trading Scheme (NZ ETS)?
clauses.answer: Advising the Government on policy settings in the NZ ETS

clauses.question: 13. The Government has proposed that Climate Change Commissioners need to have a range of essential and desirable expertise. Do you agree with the proposed expertise? See p45 Our Climate Your Say
clauses.notes:
The range of expertise seems sensible, though I would add that public health effects from climate change could be significant and
are perhaps warranted on the panel.

clauses.question: 14. Do you think the Zero Carbon Bill should cover adapting to climate change?
clauses.notes:
The two functions seem to link together strongly, and the bills function of limiting potential runaway climate change will not
necessarily prevent already locked in climate change. It would seem redundant to have two separate bodies with such similar

functions.

clauses.question: 15. The Government has proposed a number of new functions to help us adapt to climate change. Do you agree with the proposed functions? See p47 Our Climate Your Say
clauses.notes: At the very least the information gathering sections are highly appropriate, as we cannot plan for what we do not understand.

clauses.question: 16. Should we explore setting up a targeted adaptation reporting power that could see some organisations share information on their exposure to climate change risks?
clauses.notes:
Open information is crucial to dealing effectively with the issue, and may help to prevent resources being wasted by different entities
on the same projects.

clauses.question: Do you have any other comments you'd like to make?
clauses.notes:
I believe the Zero Carbon Bill is an essential part of ensuring the future of New Zealand, and placing us as a leader among
environmentally responsible nations of the world. It can also be managed in such a way as to create new business opportunities for

New Zealanders and ensure we transition to a future focused green economy.
